Verb[edit]

mÃ¶gen (irregular, third-person singular simple present mag, past tense mochte, past participle gemocht, past subjunctive mÃ¶chte, auxiliary haben)

  1. (transitive) to like (something or someone)
    Ich mag keinen KÃ¤se. â€• I don't like cheese.
  2. (intransitive) to want to go
  3. (auxiliary, with infinitive) may (expresses a possibility, never a permission)
    Das mag ja alles stimmen. â€• That may all be true.
  4. (auxiliary, in negation, with infinitive) to be hesitant to (do something)
    Ich mag sie nicht fragen. â€• I am hesitant to ask her.
  5. (auxiliary, in the present subjunctive, with infinitive) may (paraphrases the optative).
    MÃ¶ge die Macht mit dir sein. â€• May the Force be with you.
  6. (transitive, in the past subjunctive) to want; would like (to have or to do something)
    Ich mÃ¶chte KÃ¤se. â€• I would like cheese.
    Ich mÃ¶chte keinen KÃ¤se. â€• I don't want cheese.
  7. (auxiliary, in the past subjunctive, with infinitive) to want to; would like to; to wish to (do something)
    Ich mÃ¶chte sie nicht fragen. â€• I don't want to ask her.

Usage notes[edit]

  • As with all modal verbs, the past participle gemocht is used in the perfect tenses only when the verb is not followed by another infinitive: KÃ¤se habe ich noch nie gemocht. â€“ â€œI've never liked cheese.â€ When an infinitive follows, mÃ¶gen itself also stands in the infinitive (double infinitive construction): Ich habe sie nicht fragen mÃ¶gen. â€“ â€œI was hesitant to ask her.â€
  • MÃ¶chte and its forms are grammatically the past subjunctive of mÃ¶gen, but are never used as such in contemporary German. The conditional of mÃ¶gen needs to be paraphrased with wÃ¼rde: Wenn ich KÃ¤se mÃ¶gen wÃ¼rde, kÃ¶nnte ich viel mehr Gerichte essen. â€“ â€œIf I liked cheese, I could eat many more dishes.â€
  • MÃ¶chte is in fact used as a somewhat more polite synonym of wollen (â€œto wantâ€) in the present indicative: Wenn ich KÃ¤se mÃ¶chte, sage ich dir bescheid. â€“ â€œIf I want cheese, I'll let you know.â€ (synonymous with: Wenn ich KÃ¤se will,...). In colloquial German, the split between mÃ¶gen and mÃ¶chte is so clear-cut that the latter may be interpreted as an independent verb and hence used in the infinitive: Du hast hier gar nix zu mÃ¶chten! â€“ â€œYou're not in the position to express wishes!â€ This is, however, nonstandard.
  • In dated or regional speech, the present indicative of mÃ¶gen may be used interchangeably with mÃ¶chte, particularly in questions: Magst du was trinken? â€“ â€œWould you like something to drink?â€ This is normal in Austro-Bavarian areas. In most other regions it is less common and likely to sound affected.

Etymology[edit]

From Middle Low German mÈ«gen, from Old Saxon mugan, from Proto-Germanic *maganÄ…, from Proto-Indo-European *megÊ°-. Compare German mÃ¶gen, Dutch mogen, English may, Icelandic mega, Gothic ğŒ¼ğŒ°ğŒ²ğŒ°ğŒ½ (magan).

Verb[edit]

mÃ¶gen (third-person singular simple present mag, past tense much, past participle mucht, auxiliary verb hebben)

  1. (auxiliary) may, can, be allowed to.
    He mag dÃ¼t Johr nich in de Ferien fÃ¶hren.
    He isn't allowed to drive during the vacation this year.
  2. (auxiliary) used to express presumption, often used as the English should
    Dat mag al Klock sÃ¶ven wesen!
    It should already be 7 o'clock!
  3. (auxiliary) to wish to, to would like to
    He mag geern frÃ¶h opwaken
    He has the intention to wake up early
  4. (auxiliary) often used with glÃ¶ven or seggen, emphasizes their meaning
    Dat magst du woll seggen!
    It is well said!
  5. (transitive) to be allowed to have/take, to may have (used as a polite way to request something)
    MÃ¶Ã¶gt wi en Glas Melk?
    May we have a glass of milk?
  6. (transitive) To like.
    Ik mag em nich so geern.
    I don't like him that much.

Usage notes[edit]

The old subjunctive II form mÃ¼ch is used to express a wish. It can also be used along with an infinitive with the meaning "to want, would like, wish".
